repnme.cdata!: Benin - Borgou Region Pilot Rural Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This report rates project outcome as
            satisfactory rather than highly satisfactory. given the
            importance that the LIL places on increasing communiy
            capacity, it is imperative that project performance
            indicators are able to track changes in capacity. Moreover,
            the project had a limited impact on improving the
            participation of women in managing their socio-economic
            environment--a major project objective. Also, limited
            success was achieved in adopting new agricultural production
            technologies. The PPAR rates sustainability as likely and
            Borrower performance as highly satisfactory. However, the
            PPAR rates institutional development impact as substantial
            rather than high, as some crucial institutional issues
            received less attention than warranted. The PPAR rates
            overall Bank performance as only satisfactory: First the
            Bank did not give attention to coordination of rules and
            processes between different Bank projects that support
            similar activities in the Borgou region, often in the same
            communities. Second, with the move to budget support, the
            Bank did not effectively (and in a timely manner)
            communicate to the Borrower as to how it would continue to
            support a follow on to the Borgou Pilot. The Operation
            Evaluations Department found that these factors conveyed
            negative, confusing, and demoralizing messages to the
            Borrower and the communities. The experience of this project
            offers several important lessons for future Bank supported
            community-driven development interventions in Benin and
            elsewhere: 1) The LIL instrument is designed to support
            learning and innovation. From the Borrower's
            perspective, implied in the use of a LIL is future Bank
            support for expansion of a successful experiment. However,
            when the Bank shifts towards favoring a different lending
            approach for the country, without communicating clearly and
            in a timely manner to the Borrower as to what this means for
            follow-on support, the credibility of the LIL instrument is
            eroded. 2) The design of CDD projects needs to be realistic
            about the costs and time required to satisfactorily
            implement such operations. 3) In a CDD intervention the
            performance indicators need to be designed to monitor and
            track quantitative and qualitative progress on achievement
            of objectives. Though the quality of community participation
            in decisionmaking is dificult to measure, if no attempt is
            made to do so, it is likely to receive less attention as
            project teams become preoccupied with meeting progress on
            quantitative targets. 4) The Bank needs to harmonize the
            rules and processes in its community-based interventions in
            a given country and coordinate with donors supporting
            similar interventions in that country.

2420967.trustfund:
TF035543-BENIN - AGRICULTURE SECTOR
            INVESTMENT PROGRAM,TF035390-BENIN - AGRICULTURE SECTOR
            INVESTMENT PROGRAM

repnme.cdata!: Benin - Borgou Pilot Rural Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Borgou Pilot Rural
            Support Project for Benin was highly satisfactory, the
            sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was high and, the Bank and borrower performance were
            both highly satisfactory. The lessons learned indicated that
            strengthening rural communities and introducing more
            democratic practices in their internal organization was
            possible with relatively limited human and material
            resources. An effective transfer of responsibilities and
            resources followed quickly to community's
            organizational efforts. Decentralized procedures allowed
            communities to be responsible for the procurement process as
            part of the implementation. The rate of beneficiary
            contribution (twenty per cent in kind or in cash) requested
            by the project as a condition for co-financing did not
            constitute a major constraint for the communities. Overall,
            the communities expressed their willingness to contribute to
            a large range of micro-projects that include social
            infrastructure, agriculture productivity improvement, and
            income generating activities. The main weakness of the
            project was limited participation of women in the village in
            the organizational process, and a small number of selected
            micro-projects were specifically oriented to respond to
            women's needs.

2122036.trustfund:
TF035543-BENIN - AGRICULTURE SECTOR
            INVESTMENT PROGRAM,TF035390-BENIN - AGRICULTURE SECTOR
            INVESTMENT PROGRAM

abstracts.cdata!:
Agriculture is the mainstay of
            Benin's economy, employing 70 percent of its population
            and accounting for nearly 40 percent of its gross domestic
            product (GDP). To help the rural poor especially women
            utilize their environment in more efficient and sustainable
            ways, the World Bank in 1998 launched the Borgou pilot rural
            support project. Its primary goal was to encourage local
            institutions, village committees in particular to embrace
            collective decision-making. The project has supported 150
            basic literacy courses delivered in local languages to 2,200
            women and 2,500 men. It has also offered 262 technical
            training courses on subjects as varied as financial
            management, bee keeping, fishing, and refining crops.

repnme.cdata!: Benin - Borgou Region Pilot Rural Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Borgou Region Pilot
            Rural Support Project is to improve the capacity of rural
            women and village communities to better manage their
            socio-economic environment through: (a) improving the
            understanding of this environment; (b) improving local
            institutes to strengthen collective decision-making
            capabilities; (c) providing the populations with resources
            to implement their development plans; and (d) improving the
            capacity of the providers of goods and services to respond
            to demands from the rural communities to carry out
            sustainable development activities designed and implemented
            through a participatory approach. The project components
            include: (a) capacity building in rural villages of the
            Borgou; (b) community-based local development; and (c)
            participatory management, technical support and monitoring.
